close_symbols: MHD_Connection fields used: stop_with_error, state, pool, read_buffer_size, read_buffer, read_buffer_offset, rp.response, daemon, in_access_handler, keepalive, rq.version, rq.method, rq.url, rq.url_len, rq.headers_received, rq.headers_received_tail, write_buffer, write_buffer_size, write_buffer_send_offset, write_buffer_append_offset
Connection/state constants: MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED, MHD_CONNECTION_START_REPLY, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, MHD_CONN_MUST_CLOSE, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_SENDING
explanation:
For checking MISRA requirement about well-formed for-loops we must know any objects modified in the target function, any macros/functions invoked by the target function (because the rule treats the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body), and any macros/constants/types that affect side-effects or control flags. Specifically:

- struct MHD_Connection (full definition) and its listed fields: the target function reads and modifies many connection fields. To decide whether any for-loop clause illegally uses or modifies objects that are modified in the body (rule items 2–4), the analyzer must know exactly which objects in the connection are modified here.

- struct MHD_Response: the response object is created/used/destroyed; functions operating on it could contain for-loops or side-effects relevant to MISRA analysis.

- enum MHD_Result, MHD_NO, MHD_YES: the function tests/assigns these values; knowing their types/constants is needed to reason about control flow and whether they could be loop-control flags.

- mhd_assert: a macro that may expand to code (possibly non-trivial); must be inspected to ensure no for-loops or persistent side-effects that would affect MISRA analysis.

- CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR macro and connection_close_error function, and MHD_connection_close_: the call site uses CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR — it may expand to inline code or call connection_close_error which itself calls MHD_connection_close_. Those expansions may contain for-loops or modify objects used in loop clauses; they must be included.

- MHD_DLOG: logging macro/function used in several branches; macros can hide code (including loops) so include its definition.

- MHD_pool_deallocate and MHD_pool_reset: called to free/reset buffers; must be checked for side-effects and potential for-loops inside their implementations.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static, MHD_destroy_response, MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_, MHD_queue_response: all are called directly by the target function. Their implementations may contain for-loops or modify objects referenced in this function; MISRA analysis must see their code/definitions.

- free and NULL: standard facilities used; free has no for-loops but include for completeness to reason about side-effects on memory referenced by possible loop clauses.

- bool/true/false definitions: the rule allows a loop control flag to be a Boolean object; the analyzer must know the Boolean type and any flags (e.g., connection->in_access_handler) used as pseudo-loop flags.

- Connection/state constants (MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED, MHD_CONNECTION_START_REPLY, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, MHD_CONN_MUST_CLOSE, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_SENDING): the code sets/tests these constants; if any for-loop clauses in surrounding code used them as loop counters/flags, we must know their semantics and type.

In short, include all directly referenced macros, constants, types, and every function called by transmit_error_response_len (and the immediate functions/macros those calls invoke as macros) so the next agent can determine whether any for-statement in this function or in inlined/expanded callees violates the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rules.
